definitions: attack by throwing things repeatedly and with force at someone or something
strike or beat someone or something repeatedly with blows or missiles
fall heavily and continuously like fast rain or hail
examples: The angry crowd pelted the building with stones and bottles
Children pelted each other with snowballs during recess
The hail pelted the roof throughout the storm
Heavy rain pelted against the windows all night
The rain pelted down as we ran for shelter
Snow pelted from the dark clouds above us

definitions: write or compose something using a pen or similar writing instrument
confine animals in an enclosure or restricted space for keeping
examples: She penned a heartfelt letter to her grandmother
The author penned several novels during his career
The farmer penned the sheep before the storm arrived
They penned the chickens in the coop every night

definitions: impose a penalty on someone for breaking a rule or law
put someone at a disadvantage or treat them unfairly in a situation
examples: The referee penalized the player for a dangerous tackle
The company was penalized for violating environmental regulations
The new tax law penalizes middle-income families unfairly
Students are penalized for submitting assignments after the deadline

definitions: draw, write, or mark something using a pencil as the tool
schedule or arrange something provisionally subject to possible changes later
examples: She carefully penciled the outline before painting the portrait
The architect penciled rough sketches of the building design
Let me pencil in our meeting for Tuesday afternoon
They penciled the event for next month pending approval

definitions: go into or through something, especially with force or effort
succeed in forcing a way into or through a place or barrier
understand or discover something that is difficult to understand or hidden
examples: The nail penetrated the wood completely when hammered
Sunlight barely penetrated the thick forest canopy
Enemy forces penetrated our defensive lines at dawn
The company successfully penetrated new international markets
It took years to penetrate the mystery of the ancient text
Few people can penetrate his reserved exterior personality

definitions: force someone to retire from work with a pension payment
provide someone with a regular payment after retirement from service
examples: The company pensioned off older employees during restructuring
They pensioned him after thirty years of loyal service
The government pensioned the war veterans generously last year
The firm pensioned all employees who reached retirement age

definitions: sprinkle or season food with pepper or similar spices
hit repeatedly with small objects or bombard with many things
examples: She peppered the steak before grilling it perfectly
The chef peppered the soup with fresh black pepper
Reporters peppered the politician with difficult questions
Hail peppered the car windshield during the storm

definitions: become aware of something through the senses, especially sight or hearing
interpret or understand something in a particular way mentally
examples: She could barely perceive movement in the darkness
Dogs can perceive sounds that humans cannot hear
Many people perceive him as arrogant and unfriendly
The public perceived the policy change as beneficial

definitions: sit or rest on something narrow or high like a bird
place or position something on an edge or in a precarious position
examples: The bird perched on the telephone wire outside
She perched on the arm of the sofa
He perched his glasses on top of his head
They perched the vase precariously on the shelf edge

definitions: make something completely free from faults or defects through practice
bring something to complete development or to its final form
examples: She spent years perfecting her violin technique
The chef perfected the recipe through countless experiments
Scientists are perfecting new methods for cancer treatment
The company perfected the manufacturing process over decades

definitions: carry out, accomplish, or fulfill an action, task, or function
present a form of entertainment to an audience through acting or music
work or function in a particular way, especially well or badly
examples: The surgeon performed the operation with great skill
Students must perform several experiments in chemistry class
The orchestra will perform Beethoven's Fifth Symphony tonight
She performed the lead role in the school play
The new engine performs better than the old model
The stock market performed poorly during the recession

definitions: apply perfume or fragrant liquid to something or someone
fill or permeate a space with a pleasant smell or fragrance
examples: She perfumed herself with expensive French cologne
The attendant perfumed the linens with lavender water
Roses perfumed the entire garden with their fragrance
The incense perfumed the temple with sandalwood scent

definitions: expose someone or something to serious and immediate danger or risk
examples: The captain's reckless decision periled the entire crew
Pollution continues to peril marine life worldwide
The economic crisis periled thousands of small businesses
Reckless spending perils the company's financial future

definitions: die in a violent or sudden way, especially in tragic circumstances
decay, decompose, or lose quality to the point of being unusable
examples: Many soldiers perished in the battle that day
Hundreds perished when the ship sank in icy waters
The rubber seals had perished after years of exposure
Fresh produce will perish quickly without proper refrigeration

definitions: become more cheerful, lively, or energetic, often suddenly
brew coffee in a percolator by forcing hot water through grounds
examples: She perked up when she heard the good news
The dog's ears perked at the sound of footsteps
The coffee perked while we prepared breakfast
Fresh coffee was perking in the kitchen

definitions: treat hair with chemicals to create permanent waves or curls
examples: She decided to perm her straight hair for summer
The hairdresser permed her client's hair into tight curls
Many people permed their hair in the 1980s
The salon perms hair using the latest techniques

definitions: spread throughout something and be present in every part of it
pass through or penetrate something gradually and become diffused throughout
examples: The smell of coffee permeated the entire office
A sense of excitement permeated the crowd
Water slowly permeated through the soil layers
The dye permeated the fabric completely

definitions: give authorization or consent to someone to do something officially
make it possible for something to happen or exist
examples: The city permits construction only after thorough inspection
The manager permitted employees to leave early today
Weather permitting, we will hold the event outdoors
Time doesn't permit a longer discussion right now

definitions: bleach or treat something, especially hair, with hydrogen peroxide
examples: She peroxided her hair to achieve a platinum blonde
The dentist peroxided the patient's teeth for whitening
Many people peroxided their hair in the 1950s
The stylist peroxided the dark roots carefully

definitions: make something continue indefinitely, especially something harmful or undesirable
preserve something from oblivion or extinction through continued existence
examples: These outdated policies perpetuate inequality in society
The media often perpetuates harmful stereotypes
Museums perpetuate cultural heritage for future generations
Family traditions perpetuate memories of our ancestors

definitions: subject someone to hostility and ill-treatment, especially because of beliefs
harass or annoy someone persistently and make their life difficult
examples: The regime persecuted political dissidents for decades
Many groups have been persecuted throughout history
The bully persecuted younger students every day
She felt persecuted by her demanding supervisor

definitions: continue in a course of action despite difficulty or opposition
examples: She persevered through years of medical school
The team persevered despite numerous setbacks
Athletes must persevere through pain and exhaustion
He persevered with his research for decades

definitions: continue firmly in an opinion or course of action despite opposition
continue to exist or occur, especially beyond the usual time
examples: She persisted in her efforts despite repeated failures
The student persisted with questions until understanding
The pain persisted for several weeks after surgery
These problems have persisted for generations

definitions: cause someone to believe something through reasoning or argument
convince someone to do something through reasoning or argument
examples: The lawyer persuaded the jury of his client's innocence
Evidence persuaded scientists that the theory was correct
She persuaded her parents to let her study abroad
The salesman persuaded me to buy the extended warranty

definitions: be relevant, related, or applicable to a particular matter or situation
belong to something as a part, appendage, or legal right
examples: These regulations pertain to all company employees
The discussion pertains to next year's budget
Rights that pertain to property ownership are complex
Several responsibilities pertain to this position

definitions: corrupt someone morally or lead them away from acceptable behavior
alter or distort the original meaning or state of something
examples: Bad influences can pervert young minds easily
Power tends to pervert those who possess it
They perverted the original intent of the law
The translator perverted the meaning of the text

definitions: crush or grind substances using a pestle in a mortar
examples: She pestled the spices into a fine powder
The pharmacist pestled herbs for traditional medicine
Carefully pestle the garlic with salt until smooth
They pestled grain the traditional way for flour

definitions: stroke or pat an animal gently and affectionately with the hand
engage in sexually stimulating caressing and touching
examples: The child petted the cat gently on its head
Visitors love to pet the friendly farm animals
The teenagers were petting in the back seat
Young couples petted at the drive-in movies

definitions: make a formal written request to an authority for something
make a formal application to a court for a judicial action
examples: Citizens petitioned the government for tax reform
Students petitioned the administration to change the policy
She petitioned the court for custody of her children
The company petitioned for bankruptcy protection last month

definitions: introduce or implement something in gradual stages over time
adjust the phase or timing of something to synchronize with something else
examples: The company will phase in new policies over six months
They phased out old equipment during the upgrade
Engineers phased the signals to improve traffic flow
The technician phased the electrical circuits properly

definitions: engage in numerous casual sexual affairs, especially by a man
examples: He philandered throughout his marriage despite promises
The nobleman philandered with several court ladies
Politicians who philander often face public scandal
He spent his youth philandering instead of working

definitions: contact or speak to someone using a telephone
examples: She phones her mother every Sunday evening
Please phone the office if you'll be late
He phoned to confirm the appointment time
I'll phone you when I arrive at the airport

definitions: make a photographic copy of a document using a photocopying machine
examples: Please photocopy these documents for the meeting
She photocopied her passport for the visa application
The secretary photocopied the report for all attendees
Students may photocopy chapters from the textbook

definitions: take a photograph of someone or something using a camera
examples: The journalist photographed the historic event carefully
She photographs wildlife in their natural habitats
The wedding photographer photographed every special moment
Tourists constantly photograph the famous monument

definitions: alter or enhance a digital image using photo editing software
examples: She photoshopped the blemishes from her portrait
The magazine photoshopped the model's appearance
He photoshopped himself into the group photo
They photoshopped the background to look more dramatic

definitions: express something in a particular way through careful choice of words
examples: She phrased her criticism very diplomatically
The lawyer phrased the question to confuse the witness
How you phrase the request matters greatly
He phrased his response to avoid controversy

definitions: choose someone or something from a number of alternatives
gather or harvest crops or fruit by hand from plants
pluck the strings of a musical instrument with fingers
remove small pieces or unwanted parts from something
examples: She picked the red dress for the party
The coach picked the best players for the team
Workers picked apples from the orchard trees
We picked fresh berries for the pie
He picked his guitar while singing folk songs
She learned to pick the banjo last summer
Stop picking at your food and eat properly
She nervously picked lint from her sweater

definitions: stand outside a workplace during a strike to persuade others not to enter
enclose or fortify an area with pointed wooden stakes or pickets
examples: Workers picketed the factory for better wages
Union members picketed outside the company headquarters
They picketed the garden with white wooden stakes
Settlers picketed their camps for protection

definitions: preserve food, especially vegetables, in vinegar or brine solution
examples: She pickled cucumbers from her garden every summer
My grandmother pickled onions in spiced vinegar
They pickle various vegetables for the winter months
The recipe explains how to pickle red cabbage

definitions: have a meal outdoors or in a natural setting for pleasure
examples: The family picnicked by the lake every weekend
We picnicked in the park on sunny days
They often picnic at their favorite mountain spot
Let's picnic on the beach this afternoon

definitions: form a mental image or visualization of something in the mind
represent or show someone or something in a photograph, painting, or drawing
examples: Can you picture yourself living in Paris?
I can't picture him as a father
The artist pictured the scene in watercolors
The book pictures life in medieval times

definitions: put together individual parts to form a complete whole
gradually understand or work out something from separate facts or clues
examples: She carefully pieced the quilt from fabric scraps
Workers pieced together the broken vase
Detectives pieced together the events of that night
Scientists pieced together the fossil fragments

definitions: make a hole in something using a sharp pointed object
affect someone deeply with strong emotion or penetrate their defenses
examples: The needle pierced through the thick fabric
She had her ears pierced at the mall
The sad news pierced her heart deeply
His words pierced through her emotional armor

definitions: eat greedily or consume excessive amounts of food
live in dirty or untidy conditions without care
examples: Don't pig out on junk food before dinner
They pigged themselves on chocolate cake
He's been pigging it in that apartment
Students often pig it during college years

definitions: add or apply pigment to color something or change its color
examples: The artist pigmented the canvas with natural dyes
Scientists pigmented the solution for better visibility
They pigmented the plastic during manufacturing
The fabric was pigmented with organic compounds

definitions: place things on top of each other to form a heap or stack
accumulate or increase in quantity over time
examples: She piled books on the desk carelessly
Workers piled sandbags to prevent flooding
Work continues to pile up on my desk
Snow piled against the door during the storm

definitions: rob a place using violence, especially during war or conflict
examples: Vikings pillaged coastal villages throughout history
The invading army pillaged the conquered city
Looters pillaged stores during the riots
Pirates pillaged merchant ships for treasure

definitions: attack or ridicule someone publicly and mercilessly
examples: The press pilloried the politician for his scandal
Critics pilloried the movie for its poor plot
Social media users pilloried the celebrity's comments
The newspaper pilloried the company's unethical practices

definitions: rest one's head on something soft like a pillow for comfort
examples: She pillowed her head on his shoulder
The child pillowed his head on the soft cushion
He pillowed his injured arm on a folded jacket
She pillowed herself against the comfortable backrest

definitions: operate and control an aircraft, ship, or other vehicle
guide or navigate someone or something through a difficult situation
test or trial something before introducing it more widely
examples: She pilots commercial jets for the airline
He learned to pilot helicopters in the military
The mentor piloted her through her first year
He piloted the bill through Congress successfully
The company will pilot the program in three cities
They piloted the new curriculum last semester
